we21ejcfxrkpj6B_98Rr4Q.text: 2 words to describe. Simply overrated. I had the usual Italian dishes and nothing impresses

YXSEhx_5Wi6vobTwDFik3g.text: After watching his tv show and adventures in the US, I came to Jamie's Italian with high expectations. I like Jamie from what I know him - a down- to-earth and accessible cook.So it all started on the Saturday between Good Friday and Easter. Came by for a late dinner and we were promptly seated. We started with appetizer special bruschetta and posh fries. The tomatoes on the Ciabatta bread just tasted perfect with the cheese and herbs applied.We then ordered a selections of pastas and risotto, and shared a rump steak. My favorite was the wild mushroom risotto though I usually don't eat risotto. It was light on the taste buds and almost flawless. The spinach ravioli was just okay though the serving could have been larger. Jools tuna pasta, in contrast, came in a large serving. Not too sure why it was recommended as a favorite -  it tasted just normal. The squid ink pasta I personally ordered was fairly disappointing. It was dry and garlicky. I prefer squid ink pasta that is drenched in black sauce that leaves your mouth black after eating it. No comments on the rump steak.Desserts included the lemon meringue and tiramisu. The former had a crispy crust which was nice but I felt the lemon taste to be a little overpowering; the latter had a fairly strong alcoholic taste and though the slice was a little small, I found it delicious. I see myself coming back for the planks and other mains like the veal coupled with a glass of red wine.

aewHhLF8RRRV12TBavNqrw.text: Disappointing.  Avoid.  We were fooled by the Jamie Olivier brand, and would not return.  We had a large party. Dinner came out to be about $600, for the size of our group, I'd say it was reasonable. Service was a huge problem and big factor in botching the meal.  We ordered family style and dishes routinely came out 1 by 1 (even when we made multiple orders of the same plate). This bothered me a lot. It set a lousy tone as there was never enough food to go around, and dishes got cold as we waited for for more food to arrive. Piece meal delivery of dishes is not what a large party wants.  Additionally, we were incorrectly served dishes from other tables, and the way they were taken away from our table that was awkward and gauche.The waitstaff is nice enough though.  Our main waiter was kind, and tried to be attentive.  But the training and management at the restaurant is inept,  and you see that clearly when you have a large party.  Sadly, the food did not make up for this.We sampled most of appetizer list, most of the pastas, and for the meats we had the pork chop and lamb chops.   My girlfriend enjoyed the salads and thought they were the best part of the meal (which says a lot when you really consider it). I thought the meat dishes were nice, however the appetizers apart from the squid were bland (and not particularly healthy either). Most dished came fried yet soggy, and covered in a flavorless tomato sauce.  The arancini were the best of the sad starter lot.  The pastas and risottos were also soggy, the pasta very far from from al dente, and under spiced. The truffle risotto had a lumpy, oatmeal like texture which was pathetic. Apart from the lamb chops I'd say nothing we had felt like celebration food.  I admit I had miscalculated expectations.  This is a mega restaurant, churning out a couple hundred dinners a night, so the kitchen's priority is speed and not quality.  Wine was reasonably priced.The desserts could be skipped. You're probably better off bringing something in from Awfully Chocolate or the ABC bakery next door.  I felt it was ridiculous that a single desert for one diner came first, and we had to wait another 10 minutes for the rest of the deserts to come after.  The dessert portions are under-sized, and don't share well. In particular I'd say avoid the tiramisu.  Toward the end of the meal I was further annoyed by the sense of rush.  We were not asked if we wanted coffee. And the restaurant was aggressively wiping down tables, while the place was still half full.   So if you are craving Italian, there are plenty of superior options in Singapore.  Maybe even in Vivocity.   I was snookered by the "brand" here and took it for a mark of quality and inventiveness.  Instead we encountered something close to the opposite. This place is an ill-managed, international chain made best suited for tourists from Universal Studios. If you're the sort that's inclined to do some research before selecting a meal, I'd advise to go on the restaurant's site and look at the menu.  There aren't too many fireworks on it, and you should take your first impression seriously.  If you are considering booking a large party, and the quality of the service and food are very important, then you should consider another venue. If you still aren't convinced, walk through the restaurant first.  It's well decorated and has a good ambiance, but you probably won't be impressed by how the food looks, let alone tastes.  And if even you are, there's a decent shot the service will still somehow muck up the experience.

p83rCJ-ajGK3v9TLIv-Psw.text: Having frequented one of their London branches, I was excited to check out Jamie's Italian in Singapore. Having just opened, it is obvious they are still finding their feet. However, I was pretty pleased with my overall experience. It's not so easy to find an unstuffy, tasty and reasonably priced Italian restaurant in Singapore, and Jamie's Italian fills the void nicely. The décor is tasteful in a rustic kind of way, the menu extensive, and the service earnest. I ordered the meat platter for starter to share and for mains we ordered tuna fusilli and meatballs. The meat platter was decent and came on a nice wooden plank, but mains were more worthwhile. For dessert we had both tiramisu and panna cotta - both were OK, I have had better. The menu itself is extensive with something for everyone, and they have plenty of drinks. They also let you order a carafe of wine, instead of a bottle, which isn't so common in Singapore. The service was good, but quite hectic and a bit rehearsed. You could tell that the servers were freshly trained and were milling about all over the place. The ambience would have improved if the service staff were more relaxed and seamless. I have no doubt Jamie's Italian will be a success in Singapore as they have a crowd pleaser menu. But there is definitely room for improvement!

XNTHJudMBFiLR7Pj2K__uQ.text: The service was good. The kids menu was far better than the adult meals. The ravioli con carne were hard and the filling tasted odd. The spaghetti vongole small was smaller than a kids portion and double the price, 6 clams can't be that expensive. Overall I was let down by this dining experience.

svHQGL_1twcVo3Td_cxAQA.text: This place seems very hit-or-miss. Normally I would give 2 or 3 stars, but I would like to see their rating go down compared to restaurants that have 4 stars and actually serve reasonably priced, reliably good Italian food, like Bella Pasta.The seafood bucatini was way overcooked, like the tubes were falling apart. The "appetizer" portion of the sausage pasta was more like a sample portion. The rocket and radicchio salad was decent. The glasses of wine were kind of inexpensive and decent. The arancini were kind of dry. The tiramisu was about average for Singapore but odd in that it had very thin layers of sponge cake instead of espresso-soaked lady fingers.For $60+ per person, this should be better.

cWtx51O3Qk0H-Ov7z6B-ZQ.text: To be honest, I thought it was rather mediocre and overrated. I tried tuna fusill while my boyfriend tried linguine vongole and we accompanied our meals with a side - polenta fries.   The tuna fusill was lacking in flavour; there were spices and herbs to complement the tomato sauce but the pasta was too starchy such that it overpowered them. The elements of herbs, tomato sauce and tuna felt too singular and individual; I don't know but I like my pasta to be a bursting mouthful of flavours - harminous and layered in taste - but their tuna fusill was really at best subpar, considering you are paying 20-30 SGD for a meal. However, I really enjoyed the polenta fries. Its skin/coating is crispy fried but gooey and chewy inside.

pRRjXO40qdYl657ZfQL2dA.text: Was super excited when I heard Jamie Oliver was opening a restaurant here, so I made a date with my friend to go and nomz Italian food. I loveeeeeeeeee pasta, just to be clear. Anyway! We ordered a Vegetable plank and a Meat plank as appetizers, and small sizes of pasta - pasta alla norma (I think) and the squid ink pasta.Let me explain why this place has 3 stars. One star for the ambience - FLAWLESS.One star for the service - it was prompt.One star for the meat in the meat plank - My friend said it was "melt in your mouth/consistency of butter", which I assume is good from the foodgasm faces she was making. And here's why the place has only 3 stars.1) I ordered the vegetable plank, which consisted of about half an onion and a slice of eggplant and a slice of squash(?). I get that onions are cheap, but when you say 'vegetables' I do NOT expect half an onion. Well, for onion lovers I suppose you'll all run order that dish now. :)2) I'm not a cheese or pasta expert, but I am prettyyyyy sure al dente pasta does not mean hardasballs pasta. Also, I'd like stronger more flavorful cheeses with my Italian food. The bill came to about $60 nett... quite affordable. However, portion size and food quality was not something that made me jump around for joy. Still prefer the Sizzlelinis at Spageddies... sauce is TODIEFOR but that's a whole other review :P

photos.caption: Photo of Jamie's Italian - Singapore, Singapore. Vegetable and meat planks
Photo of Jamie's Italian - Singapore, Singapore. Le vegetables
Photo of Jamie's Italian - Singapore, Singapore

xjoVkSivSjVCXUOi9eiMQw.text: I wonder if Jaime Oliver would really put his name behind this restaurant... Service sucks big time! The wait staff would bring water to your table but not pour in your glass.. Maybe its free? Ok what about ordering a wine? Didn't ask us to try if we liked it as how it should be. Didn't pour the wine for us. Not included on the $53 price tag? There is nothing memorable about food. For two people our bill came out as $145 for two mains and a carafe. Was it worth it? Definitely no!

t7K0_zEdveugok3PEav8SQ.text: The food was absolutely delicious and the pasta fantastic. It was definitely on the pricey side but the exceptional service and atmosphere made up for this. We ordered the Italian lemonade (very much like my father used to make!), the broad bean bruschetta, the cannelloni (I found this hard to finish on my own, very cheese heavy and light on pasta) and the home style bolognese. Vegetarian dishes are very light on so beware.

photos.caption: Photo of Jamie's Italian - Singapore, Singapore. Broad bean bruschetta. Delicious!!
Photo of Jamie's Italian - Singapore, Singapore
Photo of Jamie's Italian - Singapore, Singapore. Cannelloni three ways

Eu2ndDLm0C4kwV4Sf60TbQ.text: 29th June:I'm back!Had the aged prime rib again. This time with the truffle butter. I think I prefer without.My better half ordered the honeycomb cannelloni. I tried a small bite and have to quickly wash it down with my beer. No more, thanks.Old review below:Very attentive and friendly waitresses. Good service. We came in without reservation on a public holiday at 5+pm. Didn't have to wait long for a table.Archipelago beer is malty. Very smooth and fragrant.The aged steak is fantastic. Loved the flavor. I ordered medium rare, it came slightly more medium than rare. The fries without the truffle butter is nice too, but can be a bit crispier. Next time when I'm back (yes, I'll be back), I'll get the truffle butter.The slow-cooked lasagne is not too cheesy and creamy. The sourish tomato sauce cuts through the richness.We ordered a epic brownie after finishing the main courses. We found the brownie a tad too sweet.Overall, an enjoyable meal.

photos.caption: Photo of Jamie's Italian - Singapore, Singapore
Photo of Jamie's Italian - Singapore, Singapore
Photo of Jamie's Italian - Singapore, Singapore. Prime rib with truffle butter fries

iMB8oi-lbC6FWYjdbCI6NQ.text: An Italian restaurant from an Englishman, I should've known that's not a good combination. I only ordered two dishes, bruschetta with pumpkin and ricotta, a good twist from tradition, it did deliver but the price is a bit prohibitive. For my mains, it's spaghettini with crabmeat. Well it's downhill from here. The pasta's undercooked and it tasted really starchy. The crab meats taste is also overpowering, I think it's also because it's got anchovies. Overall, this dish isn't great. The pasta I cook at home is way better than this rubbish.

photos.caption: Photo of Jamie's Italian - Singapore, Singapore. Jamie's menu

kIxbDSQLDLFGKsOfnrJtTg.text: Well my wife is English so she was terribly excited when a Jamie Oliver restaurant was opening in Singapore. In fact, she wanted to go just after the restaurant was opened but the lines were hours long at the time. We waited a while until the lines died down. When we finally went, I was completely underwhelmed. The food was so so, and very overpriced. I don't eat tomatoes so the menu choices were very limited for me. I had the squid ink pasta and ended up swapping with my wife for the seafood risotto I didn't like either, the portions were tiny and prices high. I wouldn't return. My wife liked it more than I and did go back for lunch one day and ended up meeting Jamie who was in town with his family on his way to Australia...he got a picture with him.

nUtPAAoVnYFMNUgvSTCFDQ.text: Parents, bring your babies and kids here (get free breadstick for the kids and let them sit in Stokke chairs).Everyone else, just nosh on some tasty, Italian fare.The FoodJamie's serves traditional Italian fare in easier forms.  The meat or seafood platters are well-known varieties of smoked meat or seafood and makes for a tasty starter.  I really love the polenta fries (cubes of polenta with a generous helping of parmesan cheese on top) and also get that pretty often.  Their meats (lamb, beef) were grilled and seasoned well.  I was also a fan of their pastas which had a great bite and beautiful sauces with interesting twists beyond the normal tomato sauce (yum for olives and tuna).  But I really love Jamie's because it is just so friendly for kids.  Their kids menus actually reflect real food (grilled chicken skewers, mini breakfast platters with sausage, eggs and tomatoes, etc.) and not just deep fried items.  Their breakfast/brunch is a newer addition and we've stopped in a few times when they have had promotions.  One time a server accidentally took away my barely eaten food but when I asked about my dish, they profusely apologized and cooked another portion for take away.  Gotta love great customer service!I would definitely recommend this to a family and anyone craving tasty Italian food!

p1YEXjIUTYtYKv2X1vlQsg.text: Lots of hype and expectations with Jamie Oliver's name on the restaurant. Unfortunately the quality and pricing of the food is not as impressive as the name of the celebrity chef. Appetisers of ricotta bruschetta - ($10 for one slice - ouch), crab arancini, and fried cauliflower were mediocre. Calimari was however verry good... Mains - signature prawn linguini was bland in taste though the pasta cooked well. Pork chop was average. Penne carbonara was also bland but the superfood bowl was not bad.

3J1paFHVzUUZEn9ePLNBOQ.text: Been dying to try the food since its opening and finally managed to have lunch with No Queue! Perhaps the anticipation raised my expectations cos I was fairly disappointed with the food after. We had the Mushroom Risotto (which happened to be the special for the day) and the Veal (which was a little too well done for our liking despite asking the server if we could have it medium done). Disappointing was also the service; our server sat down next to me while taking our orders (?!) and we had to get our own water. Not sure if I'll go back for the kinda price and service we got.

photos.caption: Photo of Jamie's Italian - Singapore, Singapore. Wild Mushroom Risotto (a little too salty for my taste buds)
Photo of Jamie's Italian - Singapore, Singapore. Veal

ceqnjvSdsnVLbsYDKkm0HQ.text: Soooooo tasty!  Polenta fries are crispy on the outside and amazingly fluffy on the inside. For mains, we got the squid ink spaghetti and veal flash steak. Squid ink spaghetti could have used more scallops but the pasta itself was garlicky with the perfect amount of chili tossed in. We topped off the meal with tiramisu which had a lovely liqueur flavor, best I've had! Will definitely be returning!

photos.caption: Photo of Jamie's Italian - Singapore, Singapore. Tiramisu
Photo of Jamie's Italian - Singapore, Singapore. Fish plank, squid ink spaghetti and veal flash steak
Photo of Jamie's Italian - Singapore, Singapore

3cTvyJR07C01vQCHHM5JAw.text: On the last night of our honeymoon after doing some shopping at Vivo City my wife and I thought we would treat ourselves to a nice final meal in Singapore. We have eaten at Jamie's Italian in Sydney and thought it was exceptional. We arrived right on 7pm and were informed it would be about half an hour wait, however we were able to wait inside, at the bar, happy days. They even had some little chunks of bread and oil / balsamic and thinly sliced bits of ham to nibble on while we waited. We ordered up 2 cocktails (A mojito and Jamie's Italian Singapore sling) both were nice,  as expected and you could taste the respective alcohol in each, once we knocked those over about 45 minutes had passed so we ordered two more drinks (a Florence Fizz and a large draught beer that is brewed especially for Jamie's Italian in a local Singaporean brewery) then enquired as to how much longer until we would be seated, it was only a couple more minutes and we were escorted to our table, we ended up right under the main air con vent which some people may not have liked but I'm a junkie for air con in Singapore so I was content with it. The waiter took a little while to come and take our order but when he did he was polite and attentive, he did try a sneaky sparkling water sale but we only wanted still water. My wife ordered the main portion of wild mushroom and smoked mozzarella risotto which was light and delicious, a slight criticism was that there was only a small amount of the smoked mozzarella. I had the burger Italiano with some funky fries (pretty sure burger and chips aren't traditional Italian but whatevs) and found it to be, in Jamie's words juicy, pimp and proper rustic yeah. It was big but so is my gob and my appetite so it held together and I enjoyed every bite. We got the bill and for some reason both our credit cards declined which had me concerned but the waiter quickly changed up the machine and it was all good. Phew. If I were to compare this to Jamie's Italian in Sydney I would say while the food was on par the service in the Sydney restaurant is just that little bit slicker, more affordable and the cocktails are more creative (they have a blueberry and basil cocktail which sounds like a strange combo but works a treat).

photos.caption: Photo of Jamie's Italian - Singapore, Singapore. Cocktails
Photo of Jamie's Italian - Singapore, Singapore. Food menu
Photo of Jamie's Italian - Singapore, Singapore. Burger Italiano and funky fries.

rF_IK_MHTe9MaUCMG5f9Kg.text: Jamie's Italian is exactly what it is - an Italian  casual dining restaurant that's part of a global franchise. I've heard a lot of mixed reviews, makes me wonder what people were expecting. Jamie Oliver isn't exactly cooking in the kitchen.That being said, for what it is, I think the food is GOOD. It absolutely met my expectations. We had the mushrooms and smoked mozzarella to start, that was excellent - though a bit on the salty side, along with a rocket and radicchio salad. I had the truffle risotto because they were out of crab risotto. I love risotto and this one was cooked really well. The rice had bite and the combination of truffle and Parmesan was perfect. Risottos tend to be really heavy but this was surprisingly light. The lemon meringue pie was good - very tangy and a generous helping of meringue, just the way it should be (maybe minus the candied fruit on top). Gotta give a shout out to the house wine as well, it's a good selection that's value for money.

iYAYRnWGoQw0dbonN2t4vg.text: Very disappointed in both our meal and the service. We went on a Sunday evening and they were not busy but frankly seemed as if they had never served a family before. We waited several minutes for baby chairs and several more before anyone stopped by the welcome us with menus or to start the process. When we did see staff, they were somewhat abrupt and not overly friendly. That in itself kind of turned me off even before we got our food. The portions were tiny, overpriced and not exceptional. When the largest plates on the table are the kids meals, you know something is amiss. I had the spinach ravioli. The pasta itself was well cooked but the sauce was watery and there were far too many pine nuts in the sauce. The price worked out to about $4 per ravioli - not worth it for very mediocre food. My wife had the prawn pasta - it was tasty but again, the portion minuscule. Bottom line - overpriced and not much better than run of the mill Italian chains in the U.S.  Won't be going back to this one. We were with some folks who had been before - they were convinced the portion size had shrunk since their last visit.

9ojCahfbCXTwKP8BC9B8rg.text: We've been to Jamie's 4 or 5 times now. A celebrity chef, reasonable price, and reasonable/no wait on days that are not Friday/Saturday.  What's not to love about it? If you think about any of the 'nice' Italian restaurants, it can easily cost more than $150 for 2. For the same price, you can get more food and wine at Jamie's. Good food, and although the service isn't as fancy as the 'nice' Italian restaurants, I like the ambiance -- Italian families are loud and homey -- and that's the ambience Jaime's have.They have a 'weekend plank' where you can pay $160 and get a lot of food, including the famous polenta chips. It's described for 2, but it's enough for 3 -- especially if you have Singaporean appetites. (We have Western appetites, but we were full and couldn't finish the wonderful desserts.)For a la carte, favorites that we always order: green peas and mint, tagliatelle bologanese (a classic), a bruschetta. We've been back to this place many times because for the price you get a lot of good food, and other 'nice' Italian restaurants seem overpriced compared to Jamie's.

q3LKn1FA88JCPvUy9oRWuQ.text: Pretty unspectacular and perhaps the brand outdoes the execution. Appetisers were great - we had the meat and fish planks as well as calamari and risotto balls. All were tasty and very well presented with a nice range of interesting flavours. Main courses were terribly mediocre though. Not even good- pastas were too salty and not flavourful - and te hamburger was a big letdown for my friend. Saved by nice desserts. It's a pleasant ambience for a weekday lunch, but at $52 per head, there are much much better lunch options. Come once if you must, and leave it behind.

photos.caption: Photo of Jamie's Italian - Singapore, Singapore. Seafood plank
Photo of Jamie's Italian - Singapore, Singapore. Meat plank- They brought the cans first. I thought i was supposed to pour out the sauce and was gonna open the cans!

XDHdOcM1-Yw41bmuXSP7Kg.text: My 3rd visit and look fwd the next one. Disclaimer - tough crowd tonight as 3 of 6 diners are Italian from Italy. General consensus after our meal was that everyone enjoyed their dining experience. Appetizers - polenta with freshly grated cheese and topped with fresh rosemary. Yum. A winner tonight was the seasonal bruschetta with ricotta, shaved eggplant ad other goodies. Fresh, crunchy, creamy, nutty. Party time. Mains - having tried small plates and a pasta last time, I had the baked salmon tonight. Nicely done with roasted carrots and beets, with a tasty salad on the side. My boyfriend and M had seafood bucatini which was good. A and E had veal, which they were pleased with. A2 had pasta. Wine - we had a soave white that everyone agreed was good value for money. Dessert - A had tiramisu which he was impressed by...considering he is Italian that is a big compliment to the chef. M and E (both Italian) had panecotta -- they said this was remarkable and I agree, having sneaked a taste. A2 and A3 shared the lemon merengue pie.411A wondered why I keep coming back and shared "this is honest and good food". $70/person all inclusive. We will be back. We don't go out to eat too often, but we're happy to be regulars at this place.

LjoizybGHn5WPaflTuF6Hw.text: Delicious food, good atmosphere and friendly staff. Was a bit thrown off by the amounts Jamie Oliver merchandise sold at the entrance, but once you go past that it feels like a restaurant again. Would definitely want to go back there again for the food and atmosphere.

LuFZvZFlR4Clb_UEfcWwZA.text: The restaurant was located at the end of the shopping centre, next to Harbourfront Centre. The restaurant was packed during dinner but we got our table easily as I had made reservation a week again. Although the restaurant looked quite dark at the entrance, we were swiftly showed to a bright looking table overlooking the sea view.For restaurant week, the restaurant was having a sugar and spice menu which cost $38++ for dinner. There were 2 choices for antipasti. Roasted Chilli Pepper Caprese BruschettaToasted ciabatta brushed with garlic, topped with buffalo mozzarella, sweet roasted peppers, cherry tomatoes & fresh basilBeware of the roasted peppers. While juicy, it tasted quite spicy too. The cheese was melted in the mouth.Proper Pumpkin SoupThe creamiest pumpkin soup ever, spiced with fresh nutmeg, with crispy aubergine & natural yogurtIt was a rich creamy sweet soup with a tab minty taste.For Secondi, we selected 2 out of the 3 choices available.Steak Tagliata220g Grilled Ribeye, spiced & cooked al mattone, crunchy fennel salad, wiggly chilli, loadsa herbs, zesty lemon & olive oil.The steak was cooked just nice. Interestingly flavored with the minty and zesty sauce.Our Famous Prawn LinguineFried garlicky prawns, shaved fennel, tomatoes, chilli & rocket.The linguine was soaked up the flavours, topped with juicy prawns.For desserts : Crema Alla VanigliaSweet vanilla cream topped with marshmallow meringue & cinnamon poached pear.It looked so sweet with the flamed touched meringue. It was light and sweet finish to a heavy meal.Hot Chocolate & Chilli FondantFreshly baked oozy chocolate pudding sightly spiced with chilli, with salted caramel ice cream.It was served warm, topped with ice cream. I would prefer it to be served pipping hot with the chocolate lava flowing out. It not hot enough to have the molten chocolate flow. The spicy taste was there but not too bad.On top of the restaurant week menu, we also ordered a number of dishes from the ala carte menu.Chicken Milanese ($28.50++)Free-range chicken stuffed with prosciutto & fontal cheese, breadcrumbed & topped with a free-range egg & truffle oilWhile crispy outside, inside was cheesy creamy and juicy.Parma Pizza ($27.50)It was the special pizza of the day, recommended by the staff. The pizza was light and crispy. Tomato base, topped with parma ham and rocket.Crispy Squid ($23.50++/ large)With garlic & lemon mayo, chilli, parsley & fried garlicIt looked quite small for large serving. It was crispy and chewy. Overall the food was not bad. The services was great with the funny and helpful staffs attending to us.

photos.caption: Photo of Jamie's Italian - Singapore, Singapore
Photo of Jamie's Italian - Singapore, Singapore
Photo of Jamie's Italian - Singapore, Singapore

vVVxwVdpNbq9jND6gQBBGw.text: Poor Jamie Oliver should be ashamed of himself for allowing his name to be put on this restaurant. The concept is great, the location is great, the service was good. The food falls horribly short - the Italian nachos tasted frozen. My main entree of braised beef was all fat and they were sitting on top of olive oil mashed potatoes. I adore Italian food but not from here. Very overpriced but it's worth a stop no if you're in the area.

photos.caption: Photo of Jamie's Italian - Singapore, Singapore

O3C-qS8qUlqEL-G7eK1xeg.text: In need of a hearty meal? Then you gotta go Italian, Jamie's Italian. Yes there have been hits and misses (i kinda hate that they keep updating their menu with the new items and removing old ones) but sticking to the long standing faves will satisfy your need for comfort food.If you don't know, Jamie Oliver focuses on using the best ingredients, which are meticulously sourced from producers, both in Italy and around the UK. All their staff are very knowledgeable on the dishes they serve and they are more than happy to share with you the origin of each dish, or how they are prepared and all. Meal time entertainment FTW.On the Cured Meat Plank ($16.50/pax), there's the 18 month aged San Daniele Prosciutto; hot soppressata (Southern Italian dry salami); Mortadella & bresaola; Pecorino & chilli jam on the crunchy music bread; a beautiful selection of Puglia pickles; olives & crunchy salad. All meats are sliced to order ensuring maximum freshness and flavor. If i have to eat pasta, then they better be hand made and fresh! Of course that's expected at Jamie's Italian.Bolognese is something that everyone thinks that they can make but really, it's hard to make a really delicious bolognese. Do not miss this not-so-simple dish of Tagliatelle Bolognese ($14.50)! Jamie's Italian tosses pasta together with beef, pork, red wine and butter and served with pangrattato (crunchy herby breadcrumbs), herbs, garlic, Parmesan and olive oil to give it that lovely umami and dimensions in flavor profile. The sauce is made from sieving the tomatoes (not a paste) and you can taste that freshness in each bite. Plus it's a HUGE plate. So damn good. High grade acquerello rice is used in risottos and we love how it's done in the Wild Mushroom & Smoked Mozzarella Risotto ($26.50). The rice is first cooked with Porcini mushroom stock for that earthy flavor. Parmesan, parsley, pan-fried mixed forest, oyster and Swiss brown mushrooms, as well as torn scamorza (hay smoked mozzarella) are then added to finish off the dish. The result? A super smooth, creamy, and rich plate of tasty carbs. Jamie's Italian VivoCity now also offers pizzas in their refreshed menu. Their pizza dough is made fresh daily from a combination of manitoba (a premium Italian bread flour), yeast and water. The dough is shaped through gentle stretching (not rolling) which is key to developing its crisp texture and crust. It is also served on a special stoneware plate which retains the heat and crispness of the pizzas for longer. Another irresistible carb.  For desserts, we ended with the Molten Chocolate Praline Pudding ($12.50), a rich chocolate center encased in a light chocolate sponge, served warm with a scoop of salted caramel ice cream and a sprinkle of crunchy praline.No fancy stuff at Jamie's Italian for us. The best things in life are the simple ones.

wESUeQ7pTUqGFEI56FjB3A.text: Jamie Oliver, holy cheezels. I remember watching his show on TV every Saturday morning. Merely thinking about going to his very own restaurant had me starstruck. I've tried going there twice before without a reservation, only to be told the next slot is 2 hours away. Today, we decided to make a reservation; practically the only way in. Food - I decided to give the crab spaghetti a try. I was more of a linguine girl but crab spaghetti sounded very interesting. My only experience with crab was with sambal, never pasta. I'm sorry to say that it was pretty ..meh. It tastes like crab sambal with cream and pasta. The funky chips were nice, but would have been better if there'd been some dipping sauce. My husband's Arrabiata was pretty good. Pasta was cooked well and sauce was nice and spicy. Service - It was busy (seems they're ALWAYS busy) so we had to get the waiters' attention. Nonetheless, they were friendly and jovial when serving us. Atmosphere - It was pretty hectic with the waiters buzzing around like busy bees, but it wasn't too hard getting their attention. The food took about 20 minutes to arrive, no surprise there. It was pretty congested and noisy, I could barely hear my husband even though we were sitting so close.Maybe I was expecting too much, or maybe the crab spaghetti was just a bad choice of dish.

photos.caption: Photo of Jamie's Italian - Singapore, Singapore. (Pasta) Penne Arrabiata & Crab Spaghetti (Side) Funky Chips (drinks) Mojito

1t4PQvpEqn2Df5sQaqwaRw.text: Third time visiting Jamie's! Food is always good, though perhaps the service could do with more waitstaff. Tried their special, Truffle Risotto, which was amazing. The cook on the risotto was slightly dry, which was okay for me, but my boyfriend preferred it a little wetter. Francis had the steak, and the cook was perfect, seasoned well. Moving on to the drinks, totally fell in love with the Rossini, although the amount of berry purée got significantly lesser each time I ordered.

ipJJimn1ZpUjccbJopxdZA.text: Great food and terrific service. A little pricey but you are paying for the brand here isn't it?? That besides one can't complain about the ambience, quality of the food and the service overall. Always enjoy going here and there are some good options for vegetarians too. Would certainly like to see a bit more choice for the vegetarians!!

nVhTOX0rgAlSgpId465p8Q.text: Spending our holiday in Singapore we spontaneuos stopped by for lunch. At the moment were arriving at the restaurant there weren´t many people around so we got a good place. The service was friendly but they took a little bit too long but it was still ok.I ordered linguine with prawns. There were prepared with garlic, fennel, chili, rocke and tomatoes. The portion was good and the taste as well, but I had to admire that I ate better linguine before, though they were good. It was a little bit expensive but when you know the prices in Singapore I think its normal. My company liked the food as well and we can recommand the Jamie`s. But I think when you would like to go there at the peak times, it´s really lound and full.

-bpvJCQBJgzbpzn7L4VpBg.text: Celebrity restaurant + Vivocity location + tourists = full house and LOUD NOISES, so be sure to make a reservation (and prepare to speak up!) I quite enjoyed my meal at Jamie's though I did find it pricy for the portions given. The truffle tagliatelle had good texture and the sauce went perfectly, but it could've used more truffle. Also, the small portion is not enough by itself; if you go that route I recommend ordering one more dish. I went for the bruschetta.The bruschetta was over $10 for one slice of bread. Despite punching my wallet in the face, it did taste pretty good. I was a bit disappointed that it was served 20 minutes after I finished my pasta. The same happened with my friend's salad; not sure who dropped the ball there.The Epic Brownie was delicious, but I didn't get what was epic about it. It was a thick, chocolate brownie topped with amaretto ice cream (that was melting quick) garnished with caramelised amaretti popcorn. Again, good, but epic? That's up for debate.TL;DR- Yummy food, but you'll pay for it. Kitchen/service logistics need improvement!

photos.caption: Photo of Jamie's Italian - Singapore, Singapore. Much talked about epic brownie
Photo of Jamie's Italian - Singapore, Singapore. Bruschetta (one order = one piece of bread)
Photo of Jamie's Italian - Singapore, Singapore. Truffle tagliatelle, small portion

8NxFB7HCa0AFctPBvYn-ng.text: Striking in the middle between casual and fancy, Jamie's is a nice restaurant frequented by couples and friends. There is a good view of the river near the back of the restaurant so try to get these tables if you can!My friends ordered the Truffle Tagliatelle and Squid Ink Spaghetti. The Truffle Tagliatelle was unimpressive as it was pretty monotonous and with not a lot of excitement going on in the plate. The Squid Ink Spaghetti though up-gamed the experience with its unique pasta and selections of seafood.  To be honest, if I were to have only tried their pasta options,  this place would be a 3/5 as the portions were small and didn't really justify the $$$. I ordered the Chicken Al Mattone, which was an excellent choice. The chicken came in good portions and was well complemented with arugula, mushrooms and its sauce. I would definitely recommend this dish over the Truffle Tagilatelle in terms of portion and price! Note: Free wifi upon request!

R82MlFSJsIPDyT-6zOzNkA.text: Me and my friend tried this Italian restaurant yesterday Saturday night, June 6. Although the waiting time of your order will take awhile because of the large crowd and their kitchen began busy, their staff went over to us to inform about the massive order and our order will be delayed a bit. We were so hungry but it's okay, we still hold on to our patience. After that, the food was served and I first tasted the Truffles Tagliatelle and I loveddddd it so much! The serving is quite small and price is so expensive but it tastes sooooo delicious! I loved it especially the Chicken Al Mattone. I'm actually quite satisfied with their food and I think the prices are reasonable. I would recommend this restaurant :)

photos.caption: Photo of Jamie's Italian - Singapore, Singapore. Delicious Chicken Al Mattone
Photo of Jamie's Italian - Singapore, Singapore. Crab and Avocado Bruschetta
Photo of Jamie's Italian - Singapore, Singapore. Chicken Al Mattone, Truffles Taglialette and Crab Avocado Bruschetta

uk8A2Rdpql0KxqNVpP4bVw.text: I came here for dinner on a late Sunday night around 8pm.  The restaurant didn't look busy.  Yet, the host told me there was a 60-minutes wait.  I wasn't pleased but since I was already there I waited...  (The restaurant is all the way in Vivo City in Harborfront which is very far from my hotel so returning on a different night with a reservation wasn't an option...)While I was waiting, I got even more upset when I saw there were plenty of empty tables and the host wasn't sitting any new parties...  This is what I would call a lackluster night...  Perhaps the kitchen was busy putting out orders?  Regardless, it was almost 9pm at this point.  So I walked up to the host to check and he actually said he had a table ready for me now.  (Seriously?)I was brought to a high table near the entrance.  After another 5 minutes or so, a waitress took me to my table.  I confirmed what I suspected, the restaurant wasn't busy.  The waitresses were chit-chatting.  If this restaurant didn't carry Jamie's name, I might have been more forgiving... but since it did, I was quite unhappy at this point and thought to myself, "the food better knock my socks off".  Sadly, that did not happen.This place isn't exactly cheap in Singapore's standards.  My dinner cost around S$40.  The food I ordered was bland and the presentation was just average.  Even Olive Garden tastes better in my opinion.  (Now that is just sad.)wild mushroom & smoked mozzarella risotto - I was so distracted by the undercooked risotto (there is a fine difference between undercooked and al dente!)  I didn't even noticed there was mozzarella. and the smoky part?  oh, just forget it!polenta chips - of course, what was meant to be an appetizer came after my risotto.  Again, they were so bland I had to ask for ketchup to roll them in the deep.  (I know, so wrong...)I know I should give them a second chance but making me wait when I can clearly see empty tables at a restaurant with idle servers were just the ultimate deal breaker.  If they want to create any kind of illusion of a hip place where everyone has to wait, they have failed miserably.  The only positive thing I could think of is that they gave me a big bottle of ice water so I don't have to constantly flag my server down for more water.Verdict:  There are so many dining option in Singapore why do I have to come back and let it disappoint me again?

photos.caption: Photo of Jamie's Italian - Singapore, Singapore
Photo of Jamie's Italian - Singapore, Singapore
Photo of Jamie's Italian - Singapore, Singapore

lPCYhQxHcpOd3eUblYsfjQ.text: Disappointing,  scales on fish and hard pasta The fish was nice,  except for the fish scales which were very annoying,  ravioli was nice,  rump steak, medium,  was decent but the pasta,  apparently they serve it differently than Al dente.  Tasted too hard for me.  Servers didn't seem like they enjoyed working here,  chefs cooking seemed to be arguing.

photos.caption: Photo of Jamie's Italian - Singapore, Singapore
Photo of Jamie's Italian - Singapore, Singapore
Photo of Jamie's Italian - Singapore, Singapore

GyZx1DqGhbcJr56Id85hIQ.text: Today was the second time I had lunch here. Unfortunately due to my religious dietary preference, I could not try anything that contains meat and alcohol. Both my times here, I ordered the same thing, Turbo Penne Arrabbiata. I have been craving it ever since my first try, hence that was the only thing I wanted to eat when we came here. I changed the pasta to my favourite, Fusilli. The breadcrumbs just made everything so much better.I guess if you do come here during weekends, it's best to reserve seats. I chose the outdoor seats which were fortunately quite empty. Wonder why people chose not to sit there as I thought it has an awesome sea view, facing Sentosa Island.

photos.caption: Photo of Jamie's Italian - Singapore, Singapore. Spinach & Ricotta Ravioli
Photo of Jamie's Italian - Singapore, Singapore. Turbo Penne Arrabbiata
Photo of Jamie's Italian - Singapore, Singapore. Outdoor seats

_2BPnrpByKEPgHDlpfpQfA.text: I think I have watched every single cooking show by celebrity chef Jamie Oliver (counting in the number of reruns on TLC) but never got to try his food because I had flew off to the Land of Rising Sun when he just opened the restaurant at Vivocity. Linguine Vongole ($27.50++) was the special pasta of the day (not on the menu). Tossed with Manila clams, sliced chilli's, tomatoes, parsley and anchovies, this homemade pasta dish was very light on flavour and the sauce was sweet. So light was the pasta that both of us decided to ask for some Parmesan Cheese, which descended like fluffy snow flakes. Oh boy, the cheese made a whole lot of difference to the dish. The Baked Salmon ($23++) was well seasoned and not overly cooked, though the whipped lemon "risotto" seemed more like puréed cream without any grainy texture. The desserts were not those gorgeously plated sweets but as casual as the likes of the British chef. My brownie-loving partner who has a penchant for rich dark chocolate, couldn't stop showering her praises for the Epic brownie($11.50)  after taking a bite. The seductive fudgy dark chocolate is lifted by the hints of boozyness in the amaretto ice cream and accented by crunchy popcorns, making it a rich yet none too cloying treat. Jamie's tiramisu ($11.50) has a clear division of labour between the coffee sponge and sticky mascarpone. It is definitely very robust in the java and little citrusy with the presence of orange shavings, though the overall texture was dry. The savoury dishes did not spark excitement as the desserts did. I was looking for set lunches since we came at 12 noon, but the board at the entrance wrote 3pm-5pm. Strangely, we noted that it became 12pm-5pm as we left the place. Perhaps our eyes were playing tricks on us.

photos.caption: Photo of Jamie's Italian - Singapore, Singapore
Photo of Jamie's Italian - Singapore, Singapore
Photo of Jamie's Italian - Singapore, Singapore

uHuSyzGZM839gRLc0VOG6w.text: Disclaimer first the food is AWESOME.  The menu is well designed and comprised of my favorite pasta dish from Jamie's recipe.  As a Jamie's loyalist fan, I knew I won't get disappoint.  The pasta I ordered was Octopus and mussels spaghetti -- a good dish to test execution (you can fail easily with overcooked mussles or undercooked octopus).   The dish was beautifully executed with Al dente black ink spaghetti and seafood cooked just right, then a good balance of capers, tomatoes and of course loads of garlic!!  Very pretty to look at but even better in your mouth.  Although the pasta is begging for more salt, the dish overall still deserves a 5*.  Many others complaines about the texture of their pasta but this is fresh pasta and should be enjoyed with some texture (you might as well go for dried pasta if you want it totally soft).Food aside, the decor and the atmosphere was lovely.The biggest disappointment was the service.  I avoided the crowd on a late Saturday afternoon and I didn't have to wait.  But I was asked to sit by the bar because I was dining alone.  Upon many more conversation, the hostess claimed that the restaurant was completely full (right?!) while I can see many tables are open.  Then another hostess promised to move me after 20 mins when a table is open -  a big fat lie!  I am now sitting on a tall long table and tall hard stool enjoying my idol chefs creation.  Other parties got treated the same way just left!The experience was ruined by this weird seating scam really its too bad!  Everyone else complained on the high prices but they probably sourced their hard to find ingredients overseas thus justify the price.

photos.caption: Photo of Jamie's Italian - Singapore, Singapore. You can't end a meal at Jamies without a dessert.  Tiramisu is a BIG punch of orange liquor then over the top orange zest!
Photo of Jamie's Italian - Singapore, Singapore. Beautifully plated octopus and mussles squid ink spaghetti.  Delicious too!

teqmMuK5AGJwy-888qIYDA.text: Not bad at all. Managed expectations after reading less than stellar reviews on Yelp.Party of 2, dropped by after the movies on a Saturday evening (around 9.30pm) - it was still 80% occupied. We shared 3 dishes - first dish had to be carb loaded and we chose the Tagliatelle Bologanese. Love that they had two sizes to choose from - starter size and main. The pasta was cooked just nice with a good bite and springy-ness. The meat sauce was generous - a large helping was found hidden under the pasta. Had the 220g Rump Steak as well. Comes with a side of shoe-string fries and yogurt coleslaw. Nothing really special about this dish - it was done the way you'd have expected.The baked mushroom was the best dish. A crispy crust forms just around the dish, very cheesy, mushrooms were succulent (and I thought there was an inkling of truffle smell - though my partner disagreed). Good portion to share around. 3* for now - a good option for food but will not be bothered if there's a queue/ going out of the way.

photos.caption: Photo of Jamie's Italian - Singapore, Singapore
Photo of Jamie's Italian - Singapore, Singapore
Photo of Jamie's Italian - Singapore, Singapore

x16d8iMU-0tv-DdqJh0gKg.text: Just when I thought that the hoo-haa over this restaurant has died down and decided to venture out to try it myself, I realized I was dead wrong.Being silly and wanting to try this place on a Friday night (of all nights), I was happily amazed that there was no queue. Lo and behold, the queue was only to 'log' your reservation and you had to wait for your table. I was dismayed to see that there were plenty of people before me who had queued and were probably shopping around vivocity. Nevertheless, I 'logged' my reservation for 2 as well. We were starving and waited for an hour but didn't receive any text from the place. Hence, we decided to try some place else.Next try, we came on a Monday night and guess what, we only waited 30 mins max!Our food however took quite a long while to come as we saw that diners who came after us had already started their meal. We asked the server to check and the next thing we knew, he brought us an appetizer on the house called "OUR FAMOUS POLENTA CHIPS" which was incredible! The chips weren't really chips and it simply melted in your mouth. Perfection achieved!To see if the food was up to expectation, I ordered the ordinary Tagliatelle Bologanise  (S$22), normal size. Seemed a bit pricey as the portion was small and the food quality was passable to me. Wasn't a WOW that I would expect from the vibe that this place has generated over the past few months. Our appetizer of Fennel & Orange Salad came in a very sad-looking portion. The dish looked so unappetizing that my remark was "...is this really the kind of thing they would serve here? just a few leaves and orange peel thrown together. Oh Gosh!" It looked like something I would put together from a 2-star hotel buffet spread. My advice is not to order this dish, there are better appetizers on the menu.We wanted to try the Tiramisu which was apparently their most popular dessert but we were stuffed from dinner and decided on the simple dessert of Affogato. Though simple (Coffee and ice cream), it was perfect in its combination - we thoroughly enjoyed it!I would need some time before I would be willing to try this place again. But next time, I would try the mains!Tip: Come on a Monday night if you want to try this place! Fastest service guaranteed.

photos.caption: Photo of Jamie's Italian - Singapore, Singapore
Photo of Jamie's Italian - Singapore, Singapore
Photo of Jamie's Italian - Singapore, Singapore

TFhb0ZFNNFHB4v2xdrh2tQ.text: Each service staff manned his/her "territory"; it was far from overstating. I was told that they could easily fill the indoor space with 230pax while another 50-60pax at the patio (could do more but some tables have been removed to widen up the walk area). I witnessed the opening ritual with all the servers lining up behind the "concierge spot"; u will be ushered to an empty seats according to the digital table plan the floor manager uses at the entrance. Jamie dons his first Asia outpost in steel-finishes and wood-pieces, pocketed leather sofa seats along with causal canteen-like movable dining furnitures, modest-looking light fixtures but gussied up with a chandelier at one spot meant for a bigger group while keeping its causality in check. The wait has been manageable, food show up fast with the Baked Mushroom S$12.50, enter the scene first. "Magic bread" - a paper-thin baked sheet that offers lighthearted crunch accompanied by a bed of juicy portobello slices cobwebbed by the gluey mozzarella, garnished with a bunch of fresh thyme before baking. The dish was minimally seasoned which I find something lacking somewhere (suit one with a lighter taste buds).The spotlight was with this Pumpkin & Smoked Mozzarella Nachos S$7.50. Not the classical corn snacks we could think of, but a deep fried Italian ravioli! I lingered at the earthy flavor eludes from the root vegetable smashed together with cheese, though the filling was slightly dry but that didn't penalize the rating. The crispy pasta adds scores while the sweet "amaretti cookie" (Italian macaroon alike) crumbles topping the nachos magically brought out the unique saltiness in the arrabbiata sauce. Don't get intimidated by the word "fiery", the Italian dipping sauce is not spicy at all. The Italians named it "angry" because of the chili element in the bell pepper. This is one of the "tryable" antipasti at Jamie's.The one that stole the limelight at the entire meal session was the 30-days matured Prime Ribs. Presented in a chop-off tree bark, this 350g piece was beautifully cooked to medium with a tantalising charred surface, evenly and modestly seasoned in a memorable peppery accent. The angus cut was sublime - piped in juice, oozing from its baby pink moist texture. Tender with a good chew perfected by the honeyed balsamic dressings mixed wild mushroom greens - endives are crunchy with an intense peppery flavor from the rocket leaves. The portion fills a gentleman comfortably but somewhat excessive for a lady, so sharing out will be an optional to savor this well-executed S$59.50 piece of strip loin. Leave out the truffle butter/shaven truffles (additional S$5), the meat is good on its own.The Prawn Linguine was a decent choice but less remarkable. I had a smaller serving for S$17 while a regular bowl tags a S$25. Gently garlic-scented in the clear tomato broth, the chili elicit more heat than I expected. The cut-up prawns were responded well with a light crunch and very succulent. Excited with freshly handmade pasta but dispirited by the bite - even the exterior of each strands were hard; not center-hard like what defines al dente. The daily pasta-making-effort in the house has gone to waste. I shall opt for a risotto when I revisit.The Panna Cotta S$9, indeed emits the biggest spark in tandem with its eulogization! Simplicity with a impressive consummation. Heighten by its sweetness, I went weak when I popped the first scoop into my mouth. I was smitten by the shivering cream gelatin on the plate as I playfully shook it; the tart berries balanced up the the candied taste in the alabaster jelly in excellence.

photos.caption: Photo of Jamie's Italian - Singapore, Singapore. Peach & lemon with basil smash!
Photo of Jamie's Italian - Singapore, Singapore. Baked mushroom
Photo of Jamie's Italian - Singapore, Singapore. Pumpkin & smoked mozzarella nachos: crispy with a mild earthy pumpkin fillings.

Y-Fhl2XkNH9m3YdwY3OlPQ.text: It was my first time at Jamie's and having heard so much about it, I left a tad bit disappointed. The service could be better as we had to wait close to twenty minutes to finally be served. I expected a bit more from the servers as they seem to be quite short staffed. The food was not bad but not quite memorable. The prawn linguine was good and the pork chop was tasty and well prepared. The overall ambience was quite comfy and laid back.

photos.caption: Photo of Jamie's Italian - Singapore, Singapore. Pork chop

_ZTY8V0VALIS_AX6dPF8yg.text: A whole new level of bad food. Everything is bland, cold, unseasoned, too oily, too messy. Go eat that hawker centre food instead... ANY HAWKER CENTRE food

photos.caption: Photo of Jamie's Italian - Singapore, Singapore. Burgers can be this bad. And ketchup with fries is actually their yesterday's marinara sauce
